The Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research, also known as Jaren 2003, decided to establish a series of prizes in collaboration with each guy for outstanding papers published in Jere.

In Rome.
The HKG Air Prize is awarded annually to an outstanding paper published in the Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research in the preceding 5 calendar years.
The prize is sponsored by each guy who contributes a $500 monetary award.
The awards committee for this year decided to give an honorable mention to it.
Paper titled Approximate Policy Iteration with the policy language Bias Solving Relational Markov decision processes by Alan Fern Sang, Koon Robert.

Given the paper presents one of the first attempts to integrate learning techniques into modern planners, the techniques it introduces for solving the complex class of relational Markov decision processes have important impact on the use of learning in classical planning.
Please join me in congratulating the authors on this honorable mention.

They each got their prize for this year, has been awarded to the paper computational feasible VCG mechanisms, coauthored by Noam Nissan in a mirror and then the citation reads.
The paper shows that classical results in mechanism design theory often fail when naively combined with suboptimal algorithms.
This results in mechanisms that is no longer necessarily truthful.
The authors propose a way of addressing this problem by giving agents a chance to improve the output.

Of the underlying algorithm, this work has been highly cited and is considered one of the starting points of what has become a major research area in artificial intelligence and algorithmic game theory.
I'm happy to present this award to the authors.
